ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: better understanding of networks, graph theory and the computational efficiencies gained by defining conditional dependence relationships. Useful survey of common techniques.
This class covers a broad range of probabilistic models.
Basic concepts covering Bayesian networks and Markov networks. Inference techniques and some representative models.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: We may need more materials (e.g. notes, slides). Other things are perfect.
rich content but lack of organization, hope to provide lecture notes.

Sekhar covered a large number of topics and is an engaging, encouraging, and knowledgeable instructor. The course could have been improved with a teaching fellow to assist Sekhar with the grading, for quicker feedback on the problem sets (though I suppose graduate courses are less structured). Despite this, Sekhar always finds time to meet with students to review topics.
I prefer a bit more applied focus, with real datasets and demonstration of useful tools for the analysis and then backing up to the theory of why what your method worked and why it's believable.
Strengths: The class expose students to different kinds of graphical models. Weakness: The lecture speed is very fast, and students who haven't never seen the materials might find it hard to follow.
I think there are too many contents included in this course and it is not easy for beginners to follow. However, it is really great to help you to review what you knew in graphical models.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: very challenging, but learned a lot. would recommend, especially for individuals interested in graph theory/network science
The topics are incredibly interesting, and Sekhar is an excellent instructor. Highly recommend.
Yes, particularly useful if you have a problem in mind and are looking for a survey of potential methods that could be applied.
The workload is not heavy and it is not that hard if you do the readings beforehand.
